<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_callback:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_callback (uint64_t size,
                                   size_t block_size,
                                   MHD_ContentReaderCallback crc,
                                   void *crc_cls,
                                   MHD_ContentReaderFreeCallback crfc)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response;

  if ((NULL == crc) || (0 == block_size))
    return NULL;
  if (NULL == (response = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_Response)
                                       + block_size)))
    return NULL;
  response->fd = -1;
  response->data = (void *) &response[1];
  response->data_buffer_size = block_size;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  if (! MHD_mutex_init_ (&response->mutex))
  {
    free (response);
    return NULL;
  }
#endif
  response->crc = crc;
  response->crfc = crfc;
  response->crc_cls = crc_cls;
  response->reference_count = 1;
  response->total_size = size;
  return response;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
response->data = (void *) &response[1];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment itself does not violate Rule 21.17: response is allocated with sizeof(struct MHD_Response) + block_size bytes and response->data is set to the byte immediately following the struct, so using up to block_size bytes at response->data is valid. A violation would occur later if a string function accesses more than block_size bytes. Example violating scenario: strcpy((char *)response->data, src) or memcpy(response->data, src, strlen(src) + 1) when strlen(src) + 1 > block_size — this would access beyond the allocated object and violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
